children.name: PulmonaryEdema
children.label: Pulmonary Edema
children.description: Pulmonary edema is a condition where fluid accumulates in the lungs, making it difficult to breathe.

children.name: Sepsis
children.label: Sepsis
children.description: Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's immune system overreacts to an infection, leading to widespread inflammation and organ damage.

children.name: SepticShock
children.label: Septic Shock
children.description: Septic shock is a life-threatening condition that occurs when an infection spreads throughout the body and causes a severe drop in blood pressure.

children.name: AcuteCOPDExacerbation
children.label: Acute Exacerbation of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (AECOPD)
children.description: AECOPD is a sudden and significant worsening of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) symptoms.

children.name: Asthma
children.label: Asthma
children.description: Asthma is a chronic lung disease that causes inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to difficulty breathing

children.name: COPD
children.label: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease
children.description: COPD is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, often requiring Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV).

children.name: ObesityHypoventilationSyndrome
children.label: Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome (OHS)
children.description: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is a breathing disorder that affects obese individuals and is characterized by chronic alveolar hypoventilation, resulting in elevated levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the blood.

children.name: ObstructiveSleepApnea(OSA)
children.label: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)
children.description: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is a common sleep disorder characterized by repeated episodes of upper airway collapse during sleep, leading to reduced or absent breathing

children.name: Empyema
children.label: Empyema
children.description: Empyema is a condition characterized by a buildup of pus in the pleural space, the cavity between the lungs and chest wall, usually caused by an infection that spreads from the lungs.

children.name: LungAbscess
children.label: Lung Abscess
children.description: A lung abscess is a pus-filled cavity in the lung tissue caused by a bacterial infection, often resulting from aspiration of oral secretions or other lung infections.

children.name: Pneumonia
children.label: Pneumonia
children.description: Peumonia is a lung infection that causes inflammation in the air sacs of the lungs

children.name: AcuteLungInjury
children.label: Acute Lung Injury
children.description: A finding of acute onset of bilateral pulmonary infiltrates by chest radiograph and a PaO2/FiO2 of less than or equal to 300, in the absence of heart failure.

children.name: AcuteRespiratoryDistress
children.label: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
children.description: ARDS is a life-threatening lung condition that causes severe difficulty breathing

children.name: AcuteRespiratoryFailure
children.label: Acute Respiratory Failure
children.description: Acute respiratory failure (ARF) is a life-threatening condition where the lungs cannot adequately exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide, leading to low oxygen levels (hypoxemia) and/or high carbon dioxide levels (hypercapnia) in the blood.

children.name: MetabolicAcidosis
children.label: Metabolic Acidosis
children.description: Metabolic acidosis is a condition in which the body accumulates too much acid in the blood, leading to a decrease in pH (acidity)

children.name: RespiratoryAcidosis
children.label: Respiratory Acidosis
children.description: Respiratory acidosis is a condition where the blood becomes too acidic due to a buildup of carbon dioxide in the lungs

children.name: AvoidingIntubation
children.label: Avoiding Intubation
children.description: Avoiding Intubation refers to the successful management of respiratory failure without the need for endotracheal intubation and invasive mechanical ventilation.

children.name: IntubationRequired
children.label: Intubation Required
children.description: Intubation is a procedure that involves inserting a tube into a patient's airway to help them breathe. It's required when a patient can't breathe on their own, or if their airway is blocked or damaged

children.name: ReductionHypercapnia
children.label: Reduction Hypercapnia
children.description: To reduce hypercapnia (excessive carbon dioxide in the blood), treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause and improving ventilation, often with non-invasive or invasive respiratory support like BiPAP, CPAP, or mechanical ventilation.

children.name: WeaningFailure
children.label: Weaning Failure
children.description: Weaning failure occurs when a patient can't pass a breathing test or needs to be reintubated after being taken off a ventilator

children.name: WeaningSuccessful
children.label: Successful Weaning
children.description: Successful weaning from mechanical ventilation, or other forms of therapy, means a patient can breathe independently without support for a certain period after extubation or decannulation, without requiring re-intubation or re-introduction of the device.

children.name: PFRatio
children.label: PaO2/FiO2 Ratio
children.description: The P/F ratio, or PaO2/FiO2 ratio, is a measure of lung function used to assess the severity of hypoxemia and is calculated by dividing the partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) by the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2)

children.name: SFRatio
children.label: SpO2/FiO2 Ratio
children.description: The S/F ratio, or SpO2/FiO2 ratio, is calculated by dividing the oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximetry (SpO2) by the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).

children.name: HematologicMalignancy
children.label: Hematologic Malignancy
children.description: Hematologic malignancy is a type of cancer that originates in the blood-forming tissues, like bone marrow, or in the cells of the lymphatic system

children.name: LungCancer
children.label: Lung Cancer
children.description: Lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung

children.name: MetastaticLungCancer
children.label: Metastatic Lung Cancer
children.description: Metastatic lung cancer, also known as stage IV lung cancer, signifies that the cancer has spread from the lungs to other parts of the body

children.name: ThoracicCancer
children.label: Thoracic Cancer
children.description: Thoracic cancer refers to cancers that develop in the chest cavity, primarily affecting the lungs, esophagus, heart, and other structures within the chest

children.name: CongestiveHeartFailure
children.label: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)
children.description: Congestive heart failure (CHF), also known as heart failure, is a condition where the heart muscle is weakened and cannot pump blood effectively

children.name: Biventricular
children.label: Biventricular
children.description: Biventricular refers to both ventricles of the heart, which are the two lower chambers that pump blood out of the heart.

children.name: CHFDiastolic
children.label: Diastolic Heart Failure (CHF)
children.description: Diastolic heart failure (CHF) is a condition where the heart muscles become stiff and cannot relax properly between heartbeats

children.name: CHFLeftSided
children.label: Left-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)
children.description: Left-sided CHF is a condition where the left ventricle of the heart cannot pump blood effectively, leading to fluid buildup in the lungs.

children.name: CHFRightSided
children.label: Right-sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)
children.description: Right-sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) occurs when the right side of the heart struggles to pump blood effectively, leading to blood buildup in the body's major organs and potentially causing fluid accumulation in the abdomen and limbs

children.name: CHFSystolic
children.label: Systolic Heart Failure (CHF)
children.description: Systolic heart failure (CHF) is a condition where the heart's left ventricle cannot pump blood effectively

children.name: CorPulmonale
children.label: Cor Pulmonale
children.description: Cor pulmonale is a condition in which the right side of the heart fails due to chronic lung diseases

children.name: HypertensionHeartFailure
children.label: Hypertension and Heart Failure
children.description: Hypertension (high blood pressure) is a major risk factor for heart failure. When hypertension is not properly controlled, it can damage the heart muscle and lead to heart failure over time.

children.name: ValvularRegurgitation
children.label: Valvular Regurgitation
children.description: Valvular regurgitation is a condition where one or more of the heart's valves does not close properly, allowing blood to flow backward (regurgitate) into the previous chamber

children.name: ValvularStenosis
children.label: Valvular Stenosis
children.description: Valvular stenosis is a condition where the valves in the heart become narrowed or thickened, preventing them from opening fully

children.name: DiabetesMellitus
children.label: Diabetes Mellitus
children.description: Diabetes mellitus, commonly known as diabetes, is a chronic metabolic disease characterized by high blood sugar (glucose) levels

children.name: DiabetesMellitusType1
children.label: Diabetes Mellitus Type 1
children.description: Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 (T1DM) is an autoimmune disease characterized by insulin deficiency due to the destruction of pancreatic beta cells.

children.name: DiabetesMellitusType2
children.label: Diabetes mellitus type 1
children.description: Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 (T2DM) is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency.

children.name: Immunosuppression
children.label: Immunosuppression
children.description: Immunosuppression is a reduction of the activation or efficacy of the immune system. Some portions of the immune system itself have immunosuppressive effects on other parts of the immune system, and immunosuppression may occur as an adverse reaction to treatment of other conditions.

children.name: Sarcoidosis
children.label: Sarcoidosis
children.description: Sarcoidosis is a disease characterized by inflammation, causing granulomas (small clumps of inflamed tissue) to form in various organs, most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes

children.name: SystemicLupusErythematosus(SLE)
children.label: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
children.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), often just called lupus, is a chronic autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own healthy tissues and organs

children.name: Vasculitis
children.label: Vasculitis
children.description: Vasculitis is a group of diseases characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels (arteries, veins, and capillaries)

children.name: ALS
children.label: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
children.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects the motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord

children.name: Guillain-BarreSyndrome
children.label: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)
children.description: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is a rare autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system, the network of nerves that connect the brain and spinal cord to the rest of the body.

children.name: MultipleSclerosis
children.label: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
children.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic, autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord).

children.name: Neuropathy
children.label: Neuropathy
children.description: Neuropathy, often called peripheral neuropathy, refers to nerve damage, typically causing pain, numbness, and weakness, especially in the hands and feet, but can also affect other body areas and functions.

children.name: Post-PolioSyndrome
children.label: Post-Polio Syndrome (PPS)
children.description: Post-polio syndrome (PPS) is a condition that can develop in people who have had polio years after their initial infection

children.name: ChronicAlcoholicMyopathy
children.label: Chronic Alcoholic Myopathy
children.description: Chronic alcoholic myopathy is a condition characterized by muscle weakness, atrophy, and pain that develops as a result of prolonged and excessive alcohol consumption.

children.name: MalignantHyperthermia
children.label: Malignant hyperthermia (MH)
children.description: Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is a rare, inherited disorder that causes a severe reaction to certain anesthetic drugs used during surgery or other medical procedures.

children.name: MuscularDystrophy
children.label: Muscular dystrophy (MD)
children.description: Muscular dystrophy (MD) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by progressive muscle weakness and degeneration, with symptoms varying depending on the specific type.

children.name: MyopathyCritical-Illness
children.label: Critical illness myopathy (CIM)
children.description: Critical illness myopathy (CIM) is a type of muscle weakness that develops in critically ill patients, typically those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission.

children.name: Rhabdomyolysis
children.label: Rhabdomyolysis
children.description: Rhabdomyolysis is a serious condition where damaged muscle tissue releases its contents, including myoglobin, into the bloodstream, potentially causing kidney damage and other complications.

children.name: AsthmaBronchospasm
children.label: Asthma with Bronchospasm
children.description: Asthma with bronchospasm results in reversible airway obstruction and can be severe in acute cases, sometimes requiring NIV.

children.name: AsthmaMild
children.label: Mild Asthma
children.description: Mild asthma presents with occasional symptoms, usually triggered by allergens or exercise, and rarely requires hospital care.

children.name: PleuralEffusionCHF
children.label: Pleural Effusion in Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)
children.description: Pleural effusion is an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, the area between the lungs and chest wall. It is a common complication of CHF.

children.name: DiabetesInsipidus
children.label: Diabetes insipidus (DI)
children.description: Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder that affects the body's ability to regulate water balance, leading to excessive thirst and urination

children.name: AcuteKidneyInjury
children.label: Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
children.description: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a sudden and significant decline in kidney function that occurs over a short period (hours to days). It is also known as acute renal failure (ARF).

children.name: ChronicKidneyDisease
children.label: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
children.description: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a long-term condition where the kidneys gradually lose their ability to filter waste products and excess fluid from the blood.

children.name: BMI
children.label: Body Mass Index (BMI)
children.description: Body Mass Index (BMI) is a measure of body weight relative to height

children.name: SmokingStatus
children.label: Smoking Status
children.description: Smoking status is a category that describes a person's relationship to smoking cigarettes.

children.name: HFNC
children.label: High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC)
children.description: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) therapy is a non-invasive respiratory support technique that delivers heated, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min) via nasal prongs, used for patients with respiratory distress or failure

children.name: Optiflow
children.label: Optiflow
children.description: Optiflow is a nasal cannula that provides respiratory support by delivering heated, humidified air and oxygen

children.name: Oximizer
children.label: Oxymizer
children.description: The Oxymizer is a type of oxygen reservoir nasal cannula, a non-invasive device that delivers oxygen more efficiently than a standard nasal cannula by storing oxygen during exhalation and releasing it during inhalation, potentially requiring lower oxygen flow rates.

children.name: Vapotherm
children.label: Vapotherm
children.description: Vapotherm a medical device that provides mask-free respiratory support through a high-velocity nasal cannula, delivering warmed and humidified gas to patients experiencing respiratory distress.

children.name: BiPAP
children.label: Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure (BiPAP)
children.description: Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) is a form of non-invasive ventilation that uses two different pressure levels: a higher pressure for inhalation (IPAP) and a lower pressure for exhalation (EPAP), delivered through a mask, to assist breathing

children.name: CPAP
children.label: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)
children.description: CPAP is a type of non-invasive ventilation (NIV) used to maintain a constant pressure in the airways

children.name: PaCO2
children.label: Partial Pressure of Carbon Dioxide (PaCO2)
children.description: PaCO2, or the partial pressure of carbon dioxide, is a measurement of the amount of carbon dioxide in the arterial blood, which is crucial for assessing respiratory function and acid-base balance

children.name: TotalCO2
children.label: Total CO2
children.description: A total CO2 blood test, also known as a bicarbonate test, measures the amount of carbon dioxide in the blood

children.name: pH
children.label: pH or "potential of Hydrogen"
children.description: pH data indicates the acidity or alkalinity of the blood, with a normal range of 7.35 to 7.45

children.name: FiO2
children.label: Fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2)
children.description: FiO2, or fraction of inspired oxygen, refers to the percentage or concentration of oxygen a person inhales, and it's a crucial factor in respiratory care, particularly when supplemental oxygen is needed.

children.name: OxygenFlowRate
children.label: Oxygen Flow Rate
children.description: Oxygen flow rate, measured in liters per minute (LPM), determines the amount of oxygen delivered to a patient and is crucial for effective oxygen therapy.

children.name: EPAP
children.label: Expiratory Positive Airway Pressure (EPAP)
children.description: EPAP is a treatment for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) that involves creating positive pressure during exhalation to keep the airway open, often using a device with valves that fit into the nostrils.

children.name: IPAP
children.label: Inspiratory Positive Airway Pressure (IPAP)
children.description: A key component of bi-level positive airway pressure (BiPAP) therapy, IPAP is the higher pressure setting used by the device during inhalation.

children.name: PEEP
children.label: Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP)
children.description: Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is a mechanical ventilation setting that maintains a positive pressure in the airways at the end of exhalation, preventing alveolar collapse and improving oxygenation

children.name: PressureSupport
children.label: Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV)
children.description: In pressure support ventilation (PSV), the ventilator provides pressure support during inspiration, with settings typically ranging from 5 to 20 cm H2O, depending on the patient's needs and the goal of the ventilation.

children.name: SetRespiratoryRate
children.label: Respiratory Rate
children.description: Respiratory rate (RR) refers to the number of breaths a person takes per minute

children.name: SpontaneousRespiratoryRate
children.label: Spontaneous Respiratory Rate
children.description: Spontaneous respiratory rate refers to the breathing rate determined by the patient's own effort, typically measured in breaths per minute, and is considered normal for adults between 12 and 20 breaths per minute.

children.name: InspiratoryFlowRate
children.label: Inspiratory Flow Rate
children.description: Inspiratory flow rate is the speed at which air is inhaled. It can refer to the flow of air during mechanical ventilation or the flow rate of a dry powder inhaler.

children.name: InspiratoryPressureSet
children.label: Peak Inspiratory Pressure (PIP)
children.description: Inspiratory pressure settings on a ventilator, particularly peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) and plateau pressure, are crucial for effective and safe mechanical ventilation, requiring careful monitoring and adjustments based on patient needs and lung mechanics.

children.name: TidalVolume
children.label: Tidal Volume (TV)
children.description: Tidal volume (TV) refers to the amount of air inhaled and exhaled during a normal breath, typically around 500 milliliters in a healthy adult

children.name: TherapyType
children.label: TherapyType
children.description:
SNOMED CT: 277132007 (Non-invasive ventilation therapy)
NCIT: C15351 (Respiratory Therapy)

children.name: BiPAP
children.label: Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure (BiPAP)
children.description: Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) is a form of non-invasive ventilation that uses two different pressure levels: a higher pressure for inhalation (IPAP) and a lower pressure for exhalation (EPAP), delivered through a mask, to assist breathing

children.name: CPAP
children.label: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)
children.description: CPAP is a type of non-invasive ventilation (NIV) used to maintain a constant pressure in the airways

children.name: HFNC
children.label: High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC)
children.description: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) therapy is a non-invasive respiratory support technique that delivers heated, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min) via nasal prongs, used for patients with respiratory distress or failure

children.name: HighFlowMask
children.label: High Flow Mask Oxygen Therapy
children.description: High-flow oxygen therapy, delivered via a HFNC device, is a non-invasive respiratory support that uses heated and humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 liters per minute) to improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing.

children.name: TherapyDuration
children.label: Therapy Duration
children.description: Duration of therapy refers to the total length of time a patient is treated, measured in days, weeks, months, or years, for a specific condition or problem

children.name: TherapyPhase
children.label: Therapy Phase
children.description: Therapy Phaseencompasses the period during which the patient is actively receiving NIV support, including the initial setup, ongoing adjustments, and monitoring for effectiveness and complications.

children.name: WeaningPhase
children.label: Weaning Phase
children.description: WeaningPhase refers to the gradual reduction or discontinuation of a treatment or support, such as mechanical ventilation, medication, or a specific therapy, as a patient's condition improves and they become more independent

children.name: InitiationTime
children.label: Initiation Time
children.description: Initiation Time refers to the time taken to start NIV therapy

children.name: PauseTime
children.label: PauseTime
children.description: Pause Time; PauseTime refers to the period between the end of inspiration and the beginning of expiration, during which airflow ceases

children.name: TerminationTime
children.label: Termination Time
children.description: Termination Time refers to the time taken to stop the therapy
